Topic.Title: buying calls anyone?

Message.Msg: In all my years of trading options I have learnt this you cannot fight a bad earnings report and a negative sentiment simultaneously. Yes sure if the earnings are bad but the sentiment is positive like for yahoo google NetFLIX or amazon you can bet on the upside but each of them are growth stories. They are revenue stories! Msft is neither ! With such a bad report and a sentiment which is so negative and rightly so there is no way for this to go up at all in the near future unless something changes drastically! $76 isn't a big amount or anything but solely from an investment point of view it is a bad trade! If you do want to play Russian roulette buy amazon the day after earnings on a dip! Now that's a strategy which works ! Or buy out Of the money calls on Netflix but msft is just a stupid Bet at this point! Until things change and I highly doubt it this has only one way to go which is down ! Also the market has reached a top here and u should be worried about the overall picture too! This will trade sideways and go down to $28 in the next week or two! Look at the volume today ! 5 times avg volume and 11%-25 billion to the downside! That should tell u something!

Message.Title: Windows 7 Migrations
Message.Msg: As a consultant and contractor, I have been involved with corporate migrations from our old friend, XP, to Windows 7 Professional, not Windows 8. Corporate America is moving to version 7 big time and the abandonment of 8 is universal. Even laptop buyers are finding, for example, that 8 is the product being pushed out and 7 has almost vanished from the retail market. Microsoft is making a huge blunder by pushing 8 at the expense of a very very good platform called Windows 7 Professional.

Message.Title: Tablet may eventually hit a saturation.
Message.Msg: Projection is tablet will be the most popular, followed by laptop, followed by desk top. My view is tablet will eventually saturate. Reason - tablets do simple function thing, such as reading, loading Bible versions for fellowship meetings, chitchatting. It does not use a lot of wear and tear and it lasts longer. Desktop is a work horse. It is difficult to write a resume at home using tablets and then print a hard copy. Desktops have the most wear-and-tear, requiring replacements may be twice a decade. Laptop is somewhere is between. I think desktop will be there for the long haul. Once most everyone is familiar with tablets, it loses its glamor, techie feel. Much like the iPhone is no longer a wow thing like in 2006 or 2007. Or the iPod for that matter. But desktop has to be there - work related..... That said, Windows being the prime OS, MSFT should be good long term.

Topic.Title: Tablet may eventually hit a saturation.

Message.Msg: "My view is tablet will eventually saturate." Tell us something we don't already know. Every product eventually saturates its market. Most people's computer usage falls well within the capability of a tablet. I personally have always said the desktop computer will never *entirely* go away, but it will decline to a tiny percentage of the total computing market. I will be among those still using a desktop, but already I use my Android-based smartphone about as much as my desktop. Windows is not likely to be widest-used OS much longer. The Linux-based Chromebook offers huge advantages over a Windows-based enterprise network -- simplified maintenance being one big factor. It is already making inroads into Microsoft's primary cash cow, and can be expected to accelerate as the word gets around among CIO's.

Message.Title: Back to school
Message.Msg: Most of the PC industry took a hit on Friday. MSFT is in most business computers. Most applications run on a Windows OS. Office and Visio are heavily used by businesses and students. Apple has been fading after the passing of Steve Job. Earning missed because of a one time write down and options expired helped hurt the stock. I think $32 to $34 is still a fair price for a company with such widely used products. They don't win at everything, but they are dominant in many areas. Hopefully we see a short squeeze and some turn around Monday.

Topic.Title: Back to school

Message.Msg: I agree. I still think $35 is good target between 6 to 12 months.

Topic.Title: Tablet may eventually hit a saturation.

Message.Msg: I think the iPad hype is just mostly hype. I think the smart phone will overtake the cell. The smart phone can do a lot of things the iPad can do. iPhone is easy store and not bulky like the iPad. Not alarming number of people carrying iPad on the street. I can visualize high school students plugging their iPad into the backpack and showing off. But they likely have desktops at home. College students may carry iPad in their backpacks also to take notes. But they have to be careful not to get their pads stolen. They also should have a desktop of at least a laptop to do serious homework. When the hype is over, may be in a few years, I think the desktop will emerge as the predominant work horse. The laptop and iPad may compete with each other for the lesser jobs. Total number of existing hardware will continue to be Desktop follow by iPads and laptops. I don't see iPads total will ever take over the total of desktops - given the existing technology.

Topic.Title: Tablet may eventually hit a saturation.

Message.Msg: A year or two ago, senior management predicted iPad may overtake the desktop. That kind of talk is no longer heard in the office. It just won't happen. I'd believe it when the total tablets in use overtakes the total desktop. Actually, we need to first see the total number of tablets and laptops combined overtakes the total desktop in use.

Topic.Title: Windows 7 Migrations

Message.Msg: My xp hard drive failed, and if weren't it being a backup for the work laptop I would have just put Oracle linux on it. As it was I got hit with a nearly $200 repair bill that moved the files to the new drive but with the evil empire's brain dead limits on xp to 2.2GB drives didn't fit on my 2.5GB drive (so no copy and just upgrade) and of course the idot idea of all time the registry can't be used on failed os attempt number 7. Thanks to the guy in malaysia for the $29 license key on ebay. But why with all the costs haven't firms woke up to here's your chrome book, your docs are in the cloud and open office is a better oa tool and tbird is your new email client? If you're going migrate then at least have the efforts have a positive roi and improved quality.

Message.Msg: who really cares? The point is that by the time it comes out the mkt will have moved to non evil ware tablets with open office and cloud based documents. CIO's will be getting nice big cost save bonuses throwing out the evil empire and it's money sucking minons. 100K employees X 12/month for failed office is 1.2M a year in savings just getting rid of evil empire office for free open office.

Topic.Title: Windows 7 Migrations

Message.Msg: Rule of thumb 1 - do not trust anything, desktop, laptop or tablet.... Always backup your data to an external drive. It is getting cheaper and cheaper. Any desktop 5 year or older should be replaced. Rule of thumb 2 - use standard software, such as MS Office and Windows. Opensource freebie should be avoided. No one is responsible for your loss.... Corporations use standard stuff.

Topic.Title: Windows 7 Migrations

Topic.Title: Tablet may eventually hit a saturation.

Message.Msg: "I think the iPad hype is just mostly hype." I think water is just mostly water. Seriously, I wouldn't have an iPad myself, I'd want an Android-based tablet. If I remember right, if you count all computing devices -- desktops, laptops, tablets, smartphones -- Windows is already a minority system, and it will continue to fade into the background as the predominance of mobile devices continues to increase. The utility of tablets will increase as technology evolves, and there will be few people who will bother with desktops.

Message.Title: MSFT is becoming irrelevant. Thanks to WinDOG 8 : The killer OS that's killing MSFT.
Message.Msg: Windows 7 is bad enough. It looks like a feeble attempt at imitating Apple OS. What's worse is, that it's mostly all visual gimmickry -- and some of it bad. For example, the familiar XP "Start" menu is replaced by a cumbersome Windog7 Start menu. Another is the "Ribbon" interface garbage at the top of every app. "Ribbon" is a re-working of the application menubar so that it;s very difficult to use. And so on. ... Oh, BTW, Windows 7 will cost about $100, and you'll probably need a heftier machine to run it. First, it's 64-bit, and second it uses oodles of memory and CPU. Enter Windog 8. - Take all the good points of WIndows 7.... take them out altogether, and make sire to KEEP ALL THE BAD STUFF OF WINDOWS 7 AND LEAVE THEM IN. Then ask a focus group to pick the user interface look-and-feel.... and they decide on "rectangles -- yes, let's add rectangles to everything!!!' Add more memory wasting bloat code, and call it WINDOWS 8 !!!!. ... Oh, and sell it for more than Windog 7!!! WHOEVER BUYS THIS GARBAGE, DESERVES IT!! Microsoft -- if you want to save your butt --- create a Microsoft LINUX distro that has integrated support for Windows ... XP !!!! .... and jettison all management employees that are belligerently anti-Linux, anti-open source. Start with BALDMER. I don't know why MSFT empoys windbags.
